intro: Matthiola livida subvar. eglandulosa, commonly known as the glandless wallflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with showy blooms. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and small, clustered flowers in shades of white, pink, and purple. Its leaves are lance-shaped and slightly hairy, and it thrives in well-drained soil in full sun. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a cut flower.
